skos.definition: The most common primary glomerulonephritis worldwide, characterized by mesangial deposition of immunoglobulin A (IgA) immune complexes, typically presenting with recurrent gross or persistent microscopic hematuria.
skos.scopeNote: Accounts for 20-40% of primary glomerulonephritis; higher prevalence in Asian populations

ICD_10.description: Recurrent and persistent hematuria with other morphologic changes in glomerulus

content.title: IgA Nephropathy (Berger Disease)
content.summary: IgA nephropathy is the most common primary glomerulonephritis worldwide, characterized by mesangial IgA deposits. It classically presents with synpharyngitic hematuria (gross hematuria within 1-2 days of upper respiratory infection). Clinical course is highly variable, ranging from benign recurrent hematuria to progressive CKD requiring renal replacement therapy.
key_points: Synpharyngitic hematuria is classic presentation (within 24-48 hours of URI)
Mesangial IgA deposits on immunofluorescence is diagnostic
Variable prognosis: 20-40% progress to ESKD over 20 years
RAAS blockade is cornerstone of treatment
content.statement: IgA nephropathy represents a disorder of mucosal immunity where aberrantly glycosylated IgA1 forms immune complexes that deposit in the mesangium, triggering inflammation and progressive glomerular injury. Early recognition and treatment of modifiable risk factors can slow progression to end-stage kidney disease.

explanation.intuition: Think of IgA nephropathy as the kidney getting caught in the crossfire of an overactive mucosal immune response. IgA is normally our first-line defender in mucous membranes (respiratory, GI tract). In IgA nephropathy, abnormal IgA molecules clump together and get trapped in the kidney's filter, causing inflammation every time there's a mucosal infection.
explanation.key_insight: The hallmark 'synpharyngitic' timing distinguishes IgA nephropathy from post-infectious GN - in IgA nephropathy, hematuria occurs during or within 1-2 days of the infection, while post-streptococcal GN has a 1-3 week latent period. This reflects the pre-existing abnormal IgA that simply gets triggered by any mucosal infection.
explanation.technical_details: Galactose-deficient IgA1 (Gd-IgA1) is the key pathogenic molecule. It is produced by mucosal B cells and forms immune complexes with anti-glycan IgG antibodies. These complexes deposit in the mesangium, activate complement (alternative and lectin pathways), and stimulate mesangial cell proliferation and matrix expansion. Genetic factors (GWAS loci) and environmental triggers (mucosal infections) contribute to disease expression.

definitions_glossary.synpharyngitic_hematuria: Gross hematuria occurring concurrently with or within 1-2 days of upper respiratory infection; classic for IgA nephropathy
definitions_glossary.mesangial_proliferation: Increased number of mesangial cells in the glomerulus; seen in IgA nephropathy
definitions_glossary.galactose_deficient_IgA1: Aberrantly glycosylated IgA1 with exposed GalNAc residues; the pathogenic molecule in IgA nephropathy
definitions_glossary.Oxford_classification: MEST-C scoring system for IgA nephropathy: Mesangial hypercellularity, Endocapillary proliferation, Segmental sclerosis, Tubular atrophy/interstitial fibrosis, Crescents
definitions_glossary.immunofluorescence: Microscopy technique using fluorescent antibodies to detect immune deposits; shows mesangial IgA in IgAN
definitions_glossary.nephritic_syndrome: Clinical syndrome of hematuria, hypertension, and reduced GFR; seen in IgA nephropathy
definitions_glossary.Henoch_Schonlein_purpura: Systemic IgA vasculitis; renal lesion is identical to IgA nephropathy
definitions_glossary.proteinuria: Protein in urine; degree correlates with prognosis in IgA nephropathy
definitions_glossary.crescentic_glomerulonephritis: Severe form with cellular crescents; indicates rapidly progressive GN
definitions_glossary.mesangial_IgA_deposits: Diagnostic finding on immunofluorescence; must be dominant or codominant immunoglobulin
definitions_glossary.RAAS_blockade: ACE inhibitors or ARBs; first-line treatment for proteinuria reduction
definitions_glossary.SGLT2_inhibitors: Newer agents showing renoprotective effects in IgA nephropathy
definitions_glossary.tonsillectomy: Removal of tonsils; may benefit some patients, particularly in Japan
definitions_glossary.corticosteroids: Immunosuppressive treatment for high-risk IgA nephropathy (TESTING trial)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Multi-hit hypothesis: (1) Increased circulating galactose-deficient IgA1, (2) Production of anti-glycan IgG antibodies, (3) Formation of pathogenic immune complexes, (4) Mesangial deposition and complement activation, (5) Mesangial proliferation and matrix expansion.
genetic_factors: GWAS loci affecting complement, innate immunity, intestinal mucosal immunity

presentations.synpharyngitic_hematuria: 50% - gross hematuria during/within 1-2 days of URI
presentations.nephrotic_syndrome: 5% - heavy proteinuria, often indicates minimal change overlap
presentations.rapidly_progressive_GN: 5% - crescentic disease with acute renal failure
presentations.chronic_kidney_disease: Some present late with established CKD

symptoms: Flank or loin pain during hematuria episodes

renal_biopsy.light_microscopy: Mesangial proliferation, variable segmental sclerosis, crescents in severe cases
renal_biopsy.immunofluorescence: Dominant or codominant mesangial IgA deposits (essential); C3 often positive; IgG and IgM variable

laboratory_findings.serum: Normal complement (C3, C4), serum IgA elevated in 50% (not diagnostic)
laboratory_findings.renal_function: Variable - may be normal or impaired

differential_diagnosis: Post-infectious glomerulonephritis (latent period 1-3 weeks, low C3)
Thin basement membrane disease (isolated hematuria, no IgA deposits)
Henoch-Schönlein purpura (systemic features: purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain)

supportive: RAAS blockade (ACE inhibitor or ARB) for proteinuria >0.5-1 g/day
Blood pressure control (target <130/80 mmHg or lower)

immunosuppression.indications: Proteinuria >1 g/day despite 3-6 months optimal supportive care, or rapidly progressive disease
immunosuppression.corticosteroids: TESTING trial: 6-month methylprednisolone/prednisone regimen (with PJP prophylaxis)
immunosuppression.mycophenolate: Used in some protocols, especially in Asian populations

other: Tonsillectomy - considered in Japan, controversial elsewhere
Budesonide (targeted-release) - NEFECON trial for gut-targeted immunomodulation

poor_prognosis_factors: High Oxford score (E1, S1, T1-2, C1-2)
prognosis.outcomes: 20-40% progress to ESKD over 20-25 years; spontaneous remission rare in adults

learning_objectives: Define IgA nephropathy and describe its pathophysiology
Recognize the classic clinical presentation of synpharyngitic hematuria
Differentiate IgA nephropathy from post-infectious glomerulonephritis
Interpret renal biopsy findings in IgA nephropathy
Apply the Oxford classification for prognosis
Outline treatment strategies including supportive care and immunosuppression
clinical_pearls: Synpharyngitic (same-time) vs post-infectious (1-3 week delay) timing is the key differentiator
Elevated serum IgA supports diagnosis but is not specific or required
Complement levels are NORMAL in IgA nephropathy (unlike post-streptococcal GN)
Heavy proteinuria is the strongest predictor of progression - treat aggressively
SGLT2 inhibitors now have evidence for slowing progression in IgA nephropathy
HSP nephritis is essentially systemic IgA nephropathy - same renal pathology

common_question_stems: Young adult with gross hematuria during URI
Renal biopsy showing mesangial IgA deposits with normal complement
Patient with IgA nephropathy and persistent proteinuria
Comparison of IgA nephropathy vs post-streptococcal GN
exam_tips: IgA nephropathy = synpharyngitic (same-time) hematuria + normal complement
Post-streptococcal GN = 1-3 week latency + LOW C3
Mesangial IgA on IF is diagnostic (must be dominant immunoglobulin)

teaching_cases.scenario: 22-year-old man with cola-colored urine for 1 day, started with sore throat yesterday. BP 145/92. Labs: Cr 1.1, normal C3/C4.
teaching_cases.key_findings: Urinalysis with dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts, proteinuria 800 mg/day, serum IgA elevated
teaching_cases.management: Renal biopsy for confirmation, start ACE inhibitor for proteinuria, monitor renal function
